TEXT:
Chief Complaint: 69 yom  with h/o CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin, DM-II
   presenting to ED with acute onset of flank pain.  Workup in the ED
   revealed right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular
   hemorrhage.  Since admission to the floor, he has received a total of 3
   units PRBC's and 6 units FFP in attempt to support patient and reverse
   INR.  Patients urine output has continued to fall and he remains
   minimally responsive to high dose Lasix bolluses.  Patient also began
   to experience asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular
   tachycardia with alternating axis
   24 Hour Events:
   - CT abd/pelvis: no significant change from prior study, areas of
   subcapsular and intraparenchymal hemorrhage without sig. increase in RP
   hematoma, small right pleural effusion, increased opacity at left lung
   base c/w atelectasis vs. aspiration
   - renal recs: urine sediment c/w ATN, dose meds for GFR = 0, agree w/
   diuretic trial
   - urology recs: reverse INR, f/u CT on Monday, follow serial HCT, will
   require MR in 3 months for further evaluation
   - bladder pressure inc. to 21 (stable), general surgery contact[**Name (NI) **] which
   reports no intervention unless > 30
   - HCT  trends down: 38.6 -> 29.5 -> 27.0 -> 25.3 -> 20.2 (1 unit) ->
   21.0 (2 units)-> 26.2 = 3 units total
   - INR trends down: 2.5 -> 2.3 -> 2.4 -> 2.2 -> 1.8 = 6 units FFP
   - Lasix boluses 80mg then 120 mg with UOP around 30 cc/hr
   - episode of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with shifting axis,
   electrolytes normal, patient asymptomatic and exam unremarkable, VSS,
   cardiac enzymes cycled and 1st set normal

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   .
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.
   -- will call urology this am to touch base about the decreased urine
   output
   -- will give another 2 units FFP given possible progression of bleed
   -- cont holding warfarin, aspirin
   -- would lke to give RBC transfusion, but will hold given volume
   .
   (#) ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: unclear what his baseline is (seems
   to be in mid 2's); acute change with minimal UOP in last few hours is
   concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to
   the kidney or IVC; also has a mildly elevated lactate.
   -- will repeat pelvis CT scan
   -Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY
   -- renal diet when restarted
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE AMI: ST changes on EKG ordered for eval of nausea (not CP,
   albeit pt is diabetic) were considered "artifact" by cards fellow and
   normalized on repeat EKG.
   -- CE ordered with am labs though low suspicion will be positive
   -- cont statin; hold ASA given bleed
   .
   (#) Fever/Leukocytosis -  WBC currently 13.6 with left shift. Infection
   is highest on differential, although stress reaction to acute bleed,
   inflammatory, and neoplastic disease are also possible. No evidence fo
   PNA currently (though may have had an aspirtaion event last night).
   -- continue to monitor
   -- Check urine culture, blood culture
   .
   # CHF (h/o systolic dysfunction, though normalized on [**2188**] echo): Pt
   reports history of mild edema and recent weight gain. Known systolic
   dysfunction although LVEF in [**2188**] >55%.
   -Strict I's and O's
   -monitor respiratory status, vital signs
   -- might consider repeat echo
   .
   #Atrial fibrillation: Hx of inducible VT, s/p upgrade to a BiV ICD [**2186**]
   (defibrillated 1x).
   -holding coumadin
   -continue telemetry
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].
   -HISS
   - [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 1936**] of [**Last Name (un) 303**] folows his DM, as pt is on a study drug for
   kidney disease
   .
   #HTN: Currently stable though on low side with possible IVC compression
   from hematoma.  Will be cautious with antihypertensives in setting of
   bleed.
   - furosemide according to BP parameters
   -hold metoprolol and valsartan, reasses if needed
   .
   #Hypothyroidism: Stable, continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   .
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   .
   # Access: peripherals
   .
   # Code: presumed full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, patient's wife [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 10486**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10487**]
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and diabetes mellitus type II. He presented to the emergency department with acute onset flank pain and was found to have right kidney intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. He has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma in an attempt to support his blood pressure and reverse the effects of warfarin. Despite these interventions, the patient's urine output continues to decline, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose lasix boluses. 

The patient also experienced episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis. A CT abdomen/pelvis revealed no significant change in the size of the hematoma. The patient has a small right pleural effusion and increased opacity at the left lung base, which could be due to atelectasis or aspiration. Renal recipients have confirmed acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and agree with a diuretic trial. Urology recommendations include reversing INR, following up with a CT scan on Monday, and conducting serial hemoglobin checks. The patient's bladder pressure has increased to 21 mmHg, and there is no need for any further intervention unless it exceeds 30 mmHg.

The patient's hemoglobin concentration has been trending downward, from 38.6 g/dL to 29.5 g

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - hold on repeat CT scan this AM as patient does not appear stable for
   study
   - consult with urology re: need for CT and how it would change
   management
   - q 6  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   - continue to trend bladder pressures for concern of abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - f/u KUB for evaluate of ileus
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - attempt Lasix 120  mg IV bolus in hopes of mobilizing fluid off lungs
   - close renal contact re: management of ARF and consideration of HD
   - renally dose all medications
   ## Hypoxia:  patient initially presented with desaturations in the ED
   with concern for volume overload as evidenced by CXR.  Patient had TTE
   performed to evaluate for cardiac function which was limited but which
   did not suggest decompensated heart failure.  Of note, patient also has
   history of obstructive lung disease and requires BiPAP at night for
   OSA.  Patient now saturating in low-mid 90
s on 4L NC.
   - continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
   - attempt diuresis as discussed above
   - continue scheduled nebulizer treatments
   - prepare for endotracheal intubation of respiratory status becomes
   worse
   - consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration PNA given episode of
   emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening CXR
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - attempt rate control with metoprolol / diltiazem
   - consult EP for pacer interrogation
   - continue to holding ASA in setting of RP bleed
   - restart home dose Metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 7**]
   ## Fever / Leukocytosis:  WBC continues to remain elevated without
   obvious infectious source.  This may represent demargination from
   generalized inflammatory response given RP bleed.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures and CXR
   ## Concern for UGIB:  patient had single reported episode of guiac
   positive post-tussive emesis in setting of severe cough.  Of note,
   patient has no risk factors variceal bleed and no history suggestive of
   UGIB.  Suspicion for UGIB is very low.
   - check stool guiac
 if positive will require GI consult
   - continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**] for now
   # CHF: unclear to extent of disease with last documented LVEF > 55%.
   TTE performed on day of admission showed mild progression of LVEF
   dysfunction.
   - continue scheduled albuterol and atrovent nebs
   - continue to attempt diuresis
   - formal echo for better evaluation of cardiac function
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Sugars have been poorly controlled in the mid-upper 200
   - increase AM Lantus to 44 units for improved basal coverage with HISS
   for breakthrough
   - contact [**Name (NI) 631**] re: DM management
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: continue allopurinol
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for possible UGIB
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, ambulation
   # Access: attain better access with 16 gauge peripheral IV
s vs.
   Midline

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) who presented to the emergency department with acute onset flank pain. The workup revealed a right kidney with intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. The patient has received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse the elevated international normalized ratio (INR).

The patient's urine output has continued to fall despite receiving high-dose Lasix boluses. Additionally, he has experienced asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.1 degrees Celsius (100.5 degrees Fahrenheit), heart rate of 99 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 98/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on CPAP mask.

The patient's laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.9 thousand/mm^3, elevated hemoglobin concentration of 26.2%, and elevated creatinine levels ranging from 4.5 to 5.8 mg/dL. The troponin-T levels have also been elevated, suggesting possible myocardial injury.

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and previous coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage of the right kidney. The patient has received 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support his hemodynamics and reverse INR. Despite this, the patient's urine output continues to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose Lasix boluses. The patient also experiences asymptomatic episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's rising creatinine levels and oliguria suggest a decline in kidney function, possibly due to the intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
2. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's marginal urine output and rising creatinine indicate worsening renal function, which may be contributing to acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
3. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen saturation is low, indicating inadequate oxygenation. This may be due to volume overload or underlying obstructive lung disease.
4. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The presence of leukocytosis and fever raises

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - repeat CT scan this AM to evaluate for interval change
   - q 8  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   ## Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - hold Lasix bolus for now considering rising Cr
   - f/u renal re: management of progressive ARF w/ poor UOP in the
   setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
   - renally dose all medications
   (#) Hypoxia: improving; patient already down to 6LNC in the ICU.
   Evidence of volume overload on CXR.  Patient also had emesis and,
   though he is not at especially high risk, may have had an aspiration
   event.  He has not gotten an extra large amount of volume aside from
   the 4 units total of FFP.  He has now received lasix 20, then 40 mg IV
   though is urine output is only 20 cc over the last three to four
   hours.  (Of note, he did have 300 cc urine recorded in flow sheet at 11
   pm last night.)  Despite to putting out urine, the patient does report
   feeling better.  Low suspicion for PE or other pathology.
   -- cont to wean oxygen and diurese as tolerated
   -- aspiration precautions if he continues to vomit
   -- antiemetics PRN
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE UGIB: Pt had episode of guaiaic positive emesis in context
   of severe cough and post-tussive emesis.  Has been nauseaus since
   admission likely from RP bleed.  Pt has no h/o ETOH abuse, liver
   disease which would be concerning for ascities.  no known ulcer
   disease; denies upper bleed such as epistaxis and dental bleeding.
   - NPO; IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - maintain active T&S
   - Maintain Hct > 25 given large degree of drop from baseline (though
   possibly hemoconcentrated on admission)
   - possible GI c/s re: UGI
   .
   (#) Retroperitoneal bleed: Differential diagnosis broad at this point.
   No recent trauma. Causes of RP bleed could include: renal maignancy,
   pyelonephritis +/- abscess, vascular disease, rupture of renal cyst.
   Subcapsular and intraparenchymal bleed makes intrinsic kidney etiology
   most likely. Exophytic lesion on upper pole noted on CT (12->22mm since
   [**2188**]) but unrelated to current bleed. Bleed most likely exacerbated by
   warfarin (although not supratherapeutic INR ~2.5) and daily baby
   aspirin (functional platelet abnormalities).  Urology is following.
   Decreased urine output is concerning for progression of bleed affecting
   renal perfusion, and Cr has bumped from 2.3 --> 4.5 overnight.
   -- will call urology this am to touch base about the decreased urine
   output
   -- will give another 2 units FFP given possible progression of bleed
   -- cont holding warfarin, aspirin
   -- would lke to give RBC transfusion, but will hold given volume
   .
   (#) ACUTE ON CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE: unclear what his baseline is (seems
   to be in mid 2's); acute change with minimal UOP in last few hours is
   concerning for progression of the hematoma compromising blood flow to
   the kidney or IVC; also has a mildly elevated lactate.
   -- will repeat pelvis CT scan
   -Continue calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY
   -- renal diet when restarted
   .
   (#) POSSIBLE AMI: ST changes on EKG ordered for eval of nausea (not CP,
   albeit pt is diabetic) were considered "artifact" by cards fellow and
   normalized on repeat EKG.
   -- CE ordered with am labs though low suspicion will be positive
   -- cont statin; hold ASA given bleed
   .
   (#) Fever/Leukocytosis -  WBC currently 13.6 with left shift. Infection
   is highest on differential, although stress reaction to acute bleed,
   inflammatory, and neoplastic disease are also possible. No evidence fo
   PNA currently (though may have had an aspirtaion event last night).
   -- continue to monitor
   -- Check urine culture, blood culture
   .
   # CHF (h/o systolic dysfunction, though normalized on [**2188**] echo): Pt
   reports history of mild edema and recent weight gain. Known systolic
   dysfunction although LVEF in [**2188**] >55%.
   -Strict I's and O's
   -monitor respiratory status, vital signs
   -- might consider repeat echo
   .
   #Atrial fibrillation: Hx of inducible VT, s/p upgrade to a BiV ICD [**2186**]
   (defibrillated 1x).
   -holding coumadin
   -continue telemetry
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].
   -HISS
   - [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 1936**] of [**Last Name (un) 303**] folows his DM, as pt is on a study drug for
   kidney disease
   .
   #HTN: Currently stable though on low side with possible IVC compression
   from hematoma.  Will be cautious with antihypertensives in setting of
   bleed.
   - furosemide according to BP parameters
   -hold metoprolol and valsartan, reasses if needed
   .
   #Hypothyroidism: Stable, continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   .

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation on coumadin, and diabetes mellitus type II. He presented to the emergency department with acute onset flank pain and was found to have right kidney intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage. 

Since admission to the floor, the patient has received a total of 3 units packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units fresh frozen plasma (FFP) in an attempt to support his hemodynamics and reverse the elevated INR. However, the patient's urine output has continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose Lasix boluses. 

The patient also began experiencing episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis. 

A 24-hour review of systems revealed no significant changes. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.1 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 99 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 98/53 mmHg to 135/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92%. 

The patient's physical examination findings include a bladder pressure of 21 mmHg, general surgery consultation reporting no intervention unless the pressure exceeds 30 mmHg, and decreased peripheral pulses

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney of unknown etiology.  Bleed appears stable with
   serial imaging.  Falling urine output and rising Cr (2.3 to 5.8) likely
   causing ATN via poor perfusion and ARF.  Patient is now s/p 3 units
   PRBC
s and 6 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
   - repeat CT scan this AM to evaluate for interval change
   - q 8  HCT w/ PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   goal < 1.9
   - hold ASA and coumadin
   - continue to trend bladder pressures for concern of abdominal
   compartment syndrome in setting of worsening renal function and ongoing
   RP bleed
   ## Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: patient with marginal UOP s/p Lasix
   bolus, rising Cr and sediment c/w ATN
   - hold Lasix bolus for now considering rising Cr
   - f/u renal re: management of progressive ARF w/ poor UOP in the
   setting of intraparenchymal hemorrhage
   - renally dose all medications
   ## Hypoxia:  patient initially presented with desaturations in the ED
   with concern for volume overload as evidenced by CXR.  Patient had TTE
   performed to evaluate for cardiac function which was limited but which
   did not suggest decompensated heart failure.  Of note, patient also has
   history of obstructive lung disease and requires BiPAP at night for
   OSA.  Patient now saturating in low-mid 90
s on 4L NC.
   - continue to wean oxygen requirements as tolerated
   - consider antibiotic coverage for aspiration PNA given episode of
   emesis if continued clinical deterioration or worsening CXR
   ## Concern for UGIB:  patient had single reported episode of guiac
   positive post-tussive emesis in setting of severe cough.  Of note,
   patient has no risk factors variceal bleed and no history suggestive of
   UGIB.  Suspicion for UGIB is very low.
   - check stool guiac
 if positive will require GI consult
   - continue IV PPI [**Hospital1 7**] for now
   - maintain active T & S
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - attempt rate control with metoprolol
   - consult EP for pacer interrogation
   - continue to holding ASA in setting of RP bleed
   ## Fever / Leukocytosis:  WBC continues to remain elevated without
   obvious infectious source.  This may represent demargination from
   generalized inflammatory response given RP bleed.
   - f/u blood and urine cultures and CXR
   # CHF: unclear to extent of disease with last documented LVEF > 55%.
   TTE performed on day of admission was not suggestive of decompensated
   HF.
   - continue strict I and O
   - continue scheduled albuterol and atrovent nebs
   - consider formal echo for better evaluation of cardiac function

   - consider increasing AM Lantus dosing for improved basal coverage with

   - contact [**Name (NI) **] [**Name2 (NI) 1936**] from [**Name (NI) 631**] re: DM management

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation, and diabetes mellitus type II.
- He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of flank pain and was found to have intraparenchymal and subcapsular hemorrhage in the right kidney.
- The patient received 3 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to support hemodynamics and reverse INR.
- Despite the transfusions, the patient's urine output continued to fall, and he remains minimally responsive to high-dose Lasix boluses.
- The patient also experienced episodes of wide complex, irregular tachycardia with alternating axis.
- A CT abdomen/pelvis showed no significant change from the prior study, with areas of subcapsular and intraparenchymal hemorrhage without significant increase in renal hematoma.
- There is a small right pleural effusion and increased opacity at the left lung base, suggestive of atelectasis versus aspiration.
- Renal records indicate urine sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN), with medication dosing for GFR = 0, in agreement with diuretic trial.
- Urology recommendations include reversing INR, following up with a CT on Monday, and monitoring serial hematocrit (HCT)

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   (1)  In AM - complained of chest discomfort and shortness of breath;
   EKG was not concerning however troponins began to rise from .06 -> .12
   -> .15 with CK-MB of 6 -> 11 -> 12.  CK-MB fractions were
   non-significant. Touched base with Dr[**Name (NI) 10535**] coverage who felt this
   was likely secondary to renal failure.
   (2) Began to desaturate into the low 90s in the morning, with use of
   accessory muscles, tachycardic; was intubated.  Despite intubation, pt
   continued to desaturate into the low 80s, with HRs of 110-120; febrile
   to 101.  Felt that patient was overbreathing the vent and sedation was
   increased.  Due to continued desaturations, esophageal balloon was
   placed for more accurate measurements of transpulmonary pressures and
   determine if reduction in chest wall compliance, given abdominal
   distension.   The transpulmonary inspiratory pressure was 11 and
   expiratory pressure was 1; PEEP was increased to 25 and tidal volumes
   were decreased from 550 to 500.  ET tube was noted to be 8 cm above
   carina; was moved down 3-4 cm.  After these adjustments, blood gas was
   mildly improved with pO2 of 71 pCO2 of 35 pH of  7.34.   This morning's
   blood gas had continued improvement with pO2 of 84 pCO2 of 39 and pH of
   7.36.
   (3) Repeat echo showed no new changes compared to [**10-31**]: inferior basal
   and inferolateral hypokinesis w/ LVEF of 40% new compared to study from
   last year.
   (4) Abdominal pressures were 26, then 19 after OG tube was placed and
   lots of fluid aspirated up.
   (5) Renal placed a port yesterday and began CVVH last night.
   (6)  Got some FFP to keep INR < 2 and got some blood to keep HCT > 25.
   HCTs were stable 25-26.
   (7) KUB obtained which showed: air + fecal material throughout small
   bowel and colon suggestive of ileus or chronic air swallowing unchanged
   from CT 1 day prior; no obstruction noted.
   (8) Broad spectrum abx started for CAP:  cef+ azithro.
   (9) CT abdomen: wasnt stable enough respiratory-wise to go down for CT

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, and systolic CHF. He presented with chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and desaturation. He was intubated due to respiratory distress and continues to experience hypoxemia despite adjustments in ventilator settings. The patient also has renal failure, an elevated white blood cell count, and fever, which may indicate an infectious process. He received blood products and fresh frozen plasma to address his coagulopathy and reverse anticoagulation therapy. The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including potential pulmonary edema, fluid overload, pneumonia, and a possible retroperitoneal bleed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient's low oxygen levels persist despite adjustments in ventilator settings. This could be due to underlying pulmonary edema, an infectious process, or dyssynchrony with the ventilator.

2. Pneumonia: The presence of fever, leukocytosis, and gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci in the sputum suggests a possible pneumonia. The patient is being covered for community-acquired pneumonia with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.

3. Fluid Overload: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and recent blood product transfusions may have contributed to fluid overload. This should be carefully managed to avoid worsening of renal function.

4. Retroperitoneal Ble

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   (1)  In AM - complained of chest discomfort and shortness of breath;
   EKG was not concerning however troponins began to rise from .06 -> .12
   -> .15 with CK-MB of 6 -> 11 -> 12.  CK-MB fractions were
   non-significant. Touched base with Dr[**Name (NI) 10535**] coverage who felt this
   was likely secondary to renal failure.
   (2) Began to desaturate into the low 90s in the morning, with use of
   accessory muscles, tachycardic; was intubated.  Despite intubation, pt
   continued to desaturate into the low 80s, with HRs of 110-120; febrile
   to 101.  Felt that patient was overbreathing the vent and sedation was
   increased.  Due to continued desaturations, esophageal balloon was
   placed for more accurate measurements of transpulmonary pressures and
   determine if reduction in chest wall compliance, given abdominal
   distension.   The transpulmonary inspiratory pressure was 11 and
   expiratory pressure was 1; PEEP was increased to 25 and tidal volumes
   were decreased from 550 to 500.  ET tube was noted to be 8 cm above
   carina; was moved down 3-4 cm.  After these adjustments, blood gas was
   mildly improved with pO2 of 71 pCO2 of 35 pH of  7.34.   This morning's
   blood gas had continued improvement with pO2 of 84 pCO2 of 39 and pH of
   7.36.
   (3) Repeat echo showed no new changes compared to [**10-31**]: inferior basal
   and inferolateral hypokinesis w/ LVEF of 40% new compared to study from
   last year.
   (4) Abdominal pressures were 26, then 19 after OG tube was placed and
   lots of fluid aspirated up.
   (5) Renal placed a port yesterday and began CVVH last night.
   (6)  Got some FFP to keep INR < 2 and got some blood to keep HCT > 25.
   HCTs were stable 25-26.
   (7) KUB obtained which showed: air + fecal material throughout small
   bowel and colon suggestive of ileus or chronic air swallowing unchanged
   from CT 1 day prior; no obstruction noted.
   (8) Broad spectrum abx started for CAP:  cef+ azithro.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient, a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), atrial fibrillation, and systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), presented with chest discomfort and shortness of breath. His troponin levels began to rise, indicating a possible myocardial infarction (MI). The patient was intubated due to desaturation and the use of accessory muscles. Despite intubation, he continued to desaturate, leading to adjustments in ventilator settings and the placement of an esophageal balloon to measure transpulmonary pressures.

The patient's abdominal pressure was high at 26 mmHg, which was reduced to 19 mmHg after placing an orogastric (OG) tube and aspirating fluid. Renal replacement therapy (RRT) was initiated, and broad-spectrum antibiotics were started for suspected community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

The patient's labs showed elevated white blood cell (WBC) count, increased creatinine levels, and elevated blood glucose. His coagulation profile revealed a high international normalized ratio (INR), indicating a bleeding risk. The patient received packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) transfusions to reverse the INR and support hemodynamics.

The patient's condition remains complex, with multiple potential complications including hypoxia, acute kidney injury (AKI), gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB), and sepsis. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with adjustments made to improve oxygenation. Antibiotics have been initiated for suspected pneumonia, and the patient is being closely monitored for any changes in vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical status.

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications include:

1. Hypoxia: The patient is experiencing hypoxia, which is likely multifactorial in etiology. Factors contributing to this include an underlying infectious process, abdominal distension reducing chest wall compliance, pulmonary edema due to biventricular heart failure, and overbreathing the ventilator.

2. Infection: The patient has been febrile, with an increasing white blood cell count. The sputum gram stain shows growth of 4+ gram-negative rods and 2+ gram-positive cocci, suggesting a possible hospital-acquired pneumonia or community-acquired pneumonia.

3. Retroperitoneal bleed: The patient has a history of acute hemorrhage of the right kidney, hypoxia, and r/o AMI. There is a possibility of a retroperitoneal bleed, possibly secondary to cyst rupture in the setting of a high INR from coumadin use.

4. Acute/chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been improving, indicating chronic kidney disease. There is a possibility of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to sustained hypotension and renal cyst rupture.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has likely underlying pneumonia
   (white count has been trending up, has been febrile, and respiratory
   sputum shows 4+ gram negative rods and 2+ gram positive cocci in pairs
   and chains.  Most likely to be community acquired since developed at
   time of admission and not coming from OSH; also not likely to be
   ventilator acquired since developed prior to being intubated.  Other
   reasons for hypoxia:  Also abdominal distension may reduce chest wall
   compliance, leading to hypoxemia.  Thirdly, he may have underlying
   pulmonary edema given his biventricular heart failure and that he
   received multiple RBCS + FFPs.  Finally, the patient is frequently
   overbreathing the ventilator and was previously in dyssynchrony with
   ventilator although seems to have improved.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 20, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP as tolerated to keep PO2 sats >
   90%.  Further improvement in CXR also suggests that respiratory status
   improvement likely secondary to continued resolution of PNA.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered for CAP with azithromycin and ceftriaxone.  White count
   still trending up, however respiratory status has improved and CXR
   looks resolved - continue coverage for CAP w/ ceftriaxone +
   azithromycin (day 4 of 8 day course).
   -Given reduced systolic function (EF of 40%) in setting of multiple
   blood products, could be fluid overloaded although radiographically
   doesn
t appear to be so.  Due to CVVH was -0.8 L overnight, overall is
   total -0.8 L.  Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or
   just slightly negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively
   diurese.
   .
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinines are steady between 4.0
   and 5.0.  Given chronic kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in
   setting of GI bleed, may have been hypotensive, which sustained, may
   have led to ATN.   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have
   further compromised renal function; may have reached new baseline.
   Continues to be oliguric (made 35 cc of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   - f/u urology recs
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -In addition to PR bisacodyl would add soap suds enema
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   -Due to ileus and distension is having difficulties with tube feeds; if
   no resolution of ileus today, may have to consider D/C tube feeds and
   trying TPN.
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.  Started
   on vancomycin yesterday to cover this until we get sensitivities.
   -1/4 bottles is growing GPCs which could be contaminant;  although gram
   stain shows gram + cocci so could be enterococcus.  For now, continue
   coverage with vancomycin (day 2).  Follow-up blood cultures and
   sensitivities.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone for CAP (day 4 of 8 day course).
   Follow up sputum cultures.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in
   69 yom with hx of CAD s/p CABG, AF on coumadin with pacer a/w acute
   hemorrhage of right kidney, hypoxia and r/o AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying Klebsiella
   pneumonia; further cx by fluid overload from receiving multiple BP (has
   CHF) and abdominal distension.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 15, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP to 10, with target of getting to 5
   as tolerated to keep PO2 sats > 90%.  Improvement in consolidation
   suggests that this improvement in respiratory status is due to
   resolution of underlying infection.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered with azithromycin and ceftriaxone which should cover both
   gram + and klebsiella and atypicals.  WBC plateau'd and now falling;
   continue  ceftriaxone + azithromycin (day 5 of 8 day course).
   -Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or just slightly
   negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively diurese.
   .
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine continuing to resolve,
   trended down to 3.6.  Cause of ARF likely secondary to ATN secondary to
   sustained hypoTN as well as intraparenchymal bleed.  Given chronic
   kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting of GI bleed, may
   have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led to ATN.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Continues to be
   oliguric (made 5cc /hr of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Aggressive bowel regimen:   PR bisacodyl, have tried soap suds enema.
   If still failing, can try milk + molasses (brown cow)
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   .
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis - Continues to be intermittently febrile but has
   largely resolved.
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Enterococcus is sensitive to ampicillin; can switch to this and
   continue to finish 10 day course.

   8 day course). Follow up sputum cultures.

   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn

   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with multiple medical complications. The patient has renal failure, respiratory failure, and a retroperitoneal bleed. He is currently in the ICU and requires ongoing monitoring and treatment for various conditions.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure due to an increase in abdominal pressures that limit the capacity to wean PEEP and maintain oxygenation. PEEP will be continued with a goal to wean to 10 today with a slow wean. The patient will also need to be monitored for FIO2 and PO2 as weaning progresses. Negative fluid balance should be maintained.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has chronic renal compromise and now has an additional insult to the right kidney. Oliguria has been maintained across time. Dialysis will continue, and there is likely a need for chronic use.

3. Hypotension: The patient's persistent decrease in blood pressure has been limited in the ability to move to a negative fluid balance. Septic/hypovolemic causes have been identified, and improvement may occur over time. Levophed will be weaned, and even fluid balance on CVVH should be maintained.

Other medical issues that need to be addressed include alterations in nutrition, anemia secondary to blood loss, heart failure (acute on chronic), diabetes mellitus (type I), chronic renal failure, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension,

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying Klebsiella
   pneumonia; further cx by fluid overload from receiving multiple BP (has
   CHF) and abdominal distension.
   -Blood gas looks good this AM even with PEEP reduced to 15, and  40%
   FiO2; could continue decrease PEEP to 10, with target of getting to 5
   as tolerated to keep PO2 sats > 90%.  Improvement in consolidation
   suggests that this improvement in respiratory status is due to
   resolution of underlying infection.
   -Sputum gram stain shows gram negative rods and gram positive cocci;
   being covered with azithromycin and ceftriaxone which should cover both
   gram + and klebsiella and atypicals.  WBC plateau'd and now falling;
   continue  ceftriaxone + azithromycin (day 5 of 8 day course).
   -Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or just slightly
   negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively diurese.
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine continuing to resolve,
   trended down to 3.6.  Cause of ARF likely secondary to ATN secondary to
   sustained hypoTN as well as intraparenchymal bleed.  Given chronic
   kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting of GI bleed, may
   have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led to ATN.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Continues to be
   oliguric (made 5cc /hr of urine yesterday).
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.  Probably may have reached new
   baseline.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   .
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Aggressive bowel regimen:   PR bisacodyl, have tried soap suds enema.
   If still failing, can try milk + molasses (brown cow)
   -Reglan for short term period (3 days)
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis - Continues to be intermittently febrile but has
   largely resolved.
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Enterococcus is sensitive to ampicillin; can switch to this and
   continue to finish 10 day course.
   -1/4 bottles is growing GPCs is likely to be contaminant; Follow-up
   blood cultures and sensitivities.
   - Continue azithromycin + ceftriaxone for CAP/klebsiella PNA (day 5 of
   8 day course). Follow up sputum cultures.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Doesn
t seem to have an active UG bleed as HCT is stable
   and does not look like frank blood.  Likely secondary to old prior
   bleed; source unclear.
   .
   -Would continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Went up on lantus yesterday.  Sugars over past 24 hours have
   been 170-230.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally
   dosed)
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes; if BM occurs today can start TF;
   if no BM may have to consider TPN.

An abdominal CT showed evidence of a right perirenal bleed possibly from a renal cyst. The patient was transferred to the ICU for multiple reasons, including possible UGIB (upper gastrointestinal bleeding), hypoxia, and possible AMI (acute myocardial infarction).

The patient has been experiencing hypoxia, which is likely multifactorial in etiology. He has underlying Klebsiella pneumonia; further exacerbation may be due to fluid overload from receiving multiple blood products (has CHF) and abdominal distension. Ventilator settings were increased overnight to maintain adequate oxygenation.

The patient's mental status is expected to be weaned off sedation. Acute/chronic renal failure is ongoing, with creatinine continuing to resolve. The cause of acute renal failure (ARF) is likely secondary to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) secondary to sustained hypotension as well as intraparenchymal bleed. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with multiple medical conditions including renal failure, diabetes mellitus type 1, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, atrial fibrillation, and a history of chronic kidney disease. The patient is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure and persistent renal failure.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, which is not ARDS, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, acute heart failure (systolic and diastolic) on chronic heart failure, type I diabetes mellitus, chronic renal failure, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, benign hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, and spontaneous retroperitoneal bleed.

The potential medical complications that can arise for this patient include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure. It is important to continue current levels of PEEP and maintain negative pressure with CVVH. Lightening sedation may also be considered.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has both chronic and acute renal failure. Continued CVVH and improvement in urine output should be monitored.

3. Hypotension: The patient remains on pressors and the antibiotic regimen has been changed to cover for specific pathogens. Other issues are being managed by the ICU team.

It is crucial to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, fluid balance, and laboratory results to ensure appropriate management of these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   ## Hypoxia
   Likely multifactorial in etiology.  Has underlying Klebsiella
   pneumonia; further cx by fluid overload from receiving multiple BP (has
   CHF) and abdominal distension.
   -Required increased vent settings overnight
 O2 increased from 40-50%,
   PEEP from [**1-11**].   (pO2 dropped to 60 - 80).   Is doing well this AM
   with blood gas of 128* 38 7.38 23.  Today, try bringing down PEEP to
   5.
   -Sputum gram stain shows Klebsiella, urine enterococcus
 sensitivities
   back.  Continue Unasyn and Cipro
   -Continue CVVH, can adjust rate to keep at balance or just slightly
   negative as per renal recs.  No need to aggressively diurese.
   ##Mental Status
 will attempt to wean sedation.
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure: Creatinine continuing to resolve,
   trended down to 2.4.  Cause of ARF likely secondary to ATN secondary to
   sustained hypoTN as well as intraparenchymal bleed.  Given chronic
   kidney disease, is more subject to ATN:  in setting of GI bleed, may
   have been hypotensive, which sustained, may have led to ATN.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Urine output continuing
   to increase:  205 ccs over 24 hrs.
   - Renal following: undergoing CVVH.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Continue to follow creatinines
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Attempted lactulose enema yesterday, but CVVH did not tolerate turning
   to side.
   -Continuing aggressive PO bowel regimen.
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis - Continues to be intermittently febrile but has
   largely resolved.
   -Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Antibiotic regimen as above.
   .
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Hematocrit stable.  Likely secondary to old prior bleed;
   source unclear.   [**Name2 (NI) 133**] continue to follow HCT.
   -Will continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - currently on metoprolol 5 mg IV q6 hrs: rate controlled with HRs <
   100
   .
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Went up on lantus yesterday.  Likely because TPN has been
   initiated, sugars over past 24 hours have been 200s - 300s.  Increase
   lantus from 48 - 52.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally
   dosed)
   # FEN: Started on TPN yesterday.  No IVF, replete electrolytes as
   necessary.
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, IV PPI
   # Access: IJ, peripherals, HD line
   # Code: full

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), atrial fibrillation with a pacemaker/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), and diabetes mellitus type II (DMII). He presents with acute onset right-sided flank pain on 10/30/2190. Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed possibly from a renal cyst. The patient was transferred to the ICU for multiple reasons including possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB), hypoxia, and possible acute myocardial infarction (AMI).

During his stay in the ICU, the patient's condition has been complicated by several issues. These include hypoxia likely due to underlying Klebsiella pneumonia, fluid overload from receiving multiple blood products, and abdominal distension. His mental status has been fluctuating, and there are concerns about acute/chronic renal failure, retroperitoneal bleed, abdominal distension, fevers/leukocytosis, concern for UGIB, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, gout, and familial end stage nephropathy (FEN).

The patient has been receiving various treatments and interventions in the ICU, including mechanical ventilation with changes in ventilator settings, continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH), blood product transfusions, aggressive bowel regimen, proton

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-year-old male with multiple medical complications. Here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure due to a retroperitoneal bleed. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 15 cmH2O and FiO2 of 40%. His ABG results show a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 320, indicating some improvement.

2. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss from hemorrhage. His Hct levels are decreasing, indicating ongoing blood loss.

3. Heart Failure (CHF): The patient has acute systolic and diastolic heart failure on top of chronic heart failure. This could be due to the hypovolemia caused by the retroperitoneal bleed.

4. Diabetes Mellitus (DM): The patient has type I diabetes mellitus. His glucose levels have been fluctuating between 228 and 276 mg/dL.

5. Renal Failure: The patient has both chronic renal failure (CRF) and acute renal failure (ARF). His creatinine levels have been rising, indicating worsening renal function. He has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).

6. Atrial Fibrillation (AFIB): The patient has atrial fibrillation, which can contribute to poor cardiac output and further compromise his renal function

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, here are the potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. There is a concern for pneumonia and the need for appropriate antibiotic therapy.

2. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss, as indicated by a decrease in hemoglobin concentration. Blood transfusions have been given, and further evaluation of reticulocyte count is needed.

3. Heart Failure: The patient has chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure. His recent echocardiogram showed improvement, but ongoing fluid overload and hypoxia may contribute to worsening heart failure.

4. Renal Failure: The patient has both acute and chronic renal failure. Acute renal failure may be due to sustained hypotension and intraparenchymal bleed. Chronic kidney disease is present, and renal function is being closely monitored.

5. Retroperitoneal Bleed: The patient has evidence of a retroperitoneal bleed, possibly secondary to cyst rupture. He has received blood transfusions to support hemodynamics and reverse INR. Daily monitoring of hemoglobin levels is necessary.

6. Abdominal Distension: The patient has abdominal distension, likely secondary to ileus. This may be contributing to respiratory compromise and needs further evaluation and management.

7. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient has had recurrent fevers and leukocytosis, suggesting an ongoing infectious process. Sources include pneumonia and urinary tract infection.

8. Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has had coffee-ground material suctioned from the OG tube, indicating possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding. This may be related to prior bleeding events.

9. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient has episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which can lead to hemodynamic instability and requires rate control.

10. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: The patient has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type II, as indicated by a recent HgA1C level of 8.5%. Insulin therapy is being initiated to manage blood glucose levels.

11. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and is receiving levothyroxine sodium supplementation.

12. Gout: The patient has gout and is being treated with allopurinol due to poor glomerular filtration rate.

13. Nutrition: The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to meet his nutritional needs.

14. Lines and Catheters: The patient has multiple lines and catheters in place, including an arterial line, dialysis catheter, and multi-lumen catheter.

15. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

The patient was transferred to the ICU for multiple reasons including possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB), hypoxia, and possible acute myocardial infarction (AMI).

The patient will continue to receive Unasyn and Cipro (double coverage for Klebsiella). Aggressive diuresis is not needed, as the patient has pre-renal azotemia. CVVH is on hold due to filter clotting.
2. Mental Status: The patient's mental status is expected to improve as sedation is weaned.

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   ## Hypoxia:
   Multifactorial: Klebsiella pneumonia; fluid overload from receiving
   multiple BP (has CHF); abdominal distension.
   -Pulm status improving -  Attempted RISBI, tolerated, but tachypneic.
   Continue to titrate down PEEP, although due to his abdominal girth, may
   require some level of PEEP.
   - treatment for klebsiella PNA and enterococcus UTI complete
   - start Vancomycin empirically for GPCs on sputum GS , should cover for
   enterococcus also
   -  No need to aggressively diurese, pre renal.  Continue CVVH
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis -  Continues to have low grade tmeperatures
   - Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Antibiotic regimen as above.
   - repeat pan culture
   - may be reaction to CVVH, given mulitple filter clots.
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.  Had another episode this morning.  Will continue to rate
   control as needed.   Had episode in setting of hypertension to 200s
   during period of extubation.  Continues to flip in an out of this
   morphology on tele.
   - cycle enzymes.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - control HR with  metoprolol 5 mg IV prn
   ##Mental Status
 will attempt to wean sedation.
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Attempted lactulose enema yesterday, but CVVH did not tolerate turning
   to side.
   -Continuing aggressive PO bowel regimen
 po narcan
   - reduced NG output
   - nutrition rec low volume elemental diet to start today
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure:  [**3-1**] to ATN from sustained
   hypotension and intraparenchymal bleed on chornic kidney disease.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Creatinine 2.7 from 3.3
   yesterday.   Making some urine:  470ccs over 24 hrs.
   - Continue CVVH
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.   Hct tredning down slowly likely a combination of slow blood loss
   and reduced reticulyte count given renal disease.  Rets appropriately.
   No evidence of hemolysis.
   - Transufsed one unit yesterday, Hct stable this mornign
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Hematocrit stable.  Likely secondary to old prior bleed;
   source unclear.   [**Name2 (NI) 133**] continue to follow HCT.
   -Will continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Likely because TPN has been initiated, sugars over past 24 hours
   have been 200s - 300s.  Home dose Lantus 44.
   - started on insulin drip for high sugars.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for the patient. These include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. There is a concern for possible ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) based on the bilateral pulmonary edema seen on chest X-ray.

2. Anemia: The patient is experiencing acute anemia secondary to blood loss from hemorrhage and retroperitoneal bleed. This can lead to decreased oxygen-carrying capacity and tissue hypoxia.

3. Heart Failure: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure, and there is concern for acute exacerbation due to fluid overload, Klebsiella pneumonia, and abdominal distension.

4. Renal Failure: The patient has chronic renal failure with an acute on chronic presentation. There is a concern for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from sustained hypotension and intraparenchymal bleed. Additionally, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised renal function.

5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with a pacemaker/defibrillator on coumadin. The recent episodes of tachycardia and chest discomfort suggest ongoing arrhythmias.

6. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient has type II diabetes mellitus with poor glycemic control as evidenced by HgA1C of 8.5%. The initiation of TPN has resulted in high blood sugars in the past 24 hours.

7. Retroperitoneal Bleed: The patient has evidence of intraparenchymal/subcapsular bleed of the right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in the setting of high INR from coumadin.

8. Upper Gastrointestinal Bleed: The patient has evidence of ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleed with coffee-ground material suctioned from the OG tube.

These are the potential medical complications that can arise for the patient based on the provided progress note.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   ## Hypoxia:
   Multifactorial: Klebsiella pneumonia; fluid overload from receiving
   multiple BP (has CHF); abdominal distension.
   -Pulm status improving -  Attempted RISBI, tolerated, but tachypneic.
   Continue to titrate down PEEP, although due to his abdominal girth, may
   require some level of PEEP.
   - treatment for klebsiella PNA and enterococcus UTI complete
   - start Vancomycin empirically for GPCs on sputum GS , should cover for
   enterococcus also
   -  No need to aggressively diurese, pre renal.  Continue dialysis
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis -  Continues to have low grade tmeperatures
   - Sources including CAP, UTI as urine is growing enterococcus.
   Antibiotic regimen as above.
   - repeat pan culture
   - may be reaction to CVVH, given mulitple filter clots.
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.  Had another episode this morning.  Will continue to rate
   control as needed.   Had episode in setting of hypertension to 200s
   during period of extubation.  Continues to flip in an out of this
   morphology on tele.
   - cycle enzymes.
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - control HR with  metoprolol 5 mg IV prn
   ##Mental Status
 will attempt to wean sedation.
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Attempted lactulose enema yesterday, but CVVH did not tolerate turning
   to side.
   -Continuing aggressive PO bowel regimen
 po narcan
   - reduced NG output
   - nutrition rec low volume elemental diet to start today
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure:  [**3-1**] to ATN from sustained
   hypotension and intraparenchymal bleed on chornic kidney disease.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Creatinine 2.7 from 3.3
   yesterday.   Making some urine:  470ccs over 24 hrs.
   - d/w renal starting HD instead of CVVH.
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.   Hct tredning down slowly likely a combination of slow blood loss
   and reduced reticulyte count given renal disease.  Rets appropriately.
   No evidence of hemolysis.
   - Transufsed one unit yesterday, Hct stable this mornign
   - daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   - holding ASA and coumadin
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Hematocrit stable.  Likely secondary to old prior bleed;
   source unclear.   [**Name2 (NI) 133**] continue to follow HCT.
   -Will continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Likely because TPN has been initiated, sugars over past 24 hours
   have been 200s - 300s.  Home dose Lantus 44.
   - started on insulin drip for high sugars.
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally

   # FEN: Start TF per nutrition, Avoiding IVF, replete electrolytes as
   necessary.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of CABG, atrial fibrillation, systolic CHF, and DMII. He presented with acute onset right-sided flank pain and was found to have evidence of a right perirenal bleed, possibly from a renal cyst. The patient was transferred to the ICU for multiple reasons, including possible UGIB, hypoxia, and possible AMI.

The patient has been diagnosed with Klebsiella pneumonia and enterococcus UTI. He has been treated with ciprofloxacin and ampicillin/sulbactam, and vancomycin has been started empirically for gram-positive cocci on sputum gram stain.

The patient continues to be mildly hypervolemic and has been unable to tolerate CVVH due to hypotension requiring pressor support. His blood pressure is currently hypertensive and off pressors. An attempt will be made today to make him 1 L negative using CVVH. Barriers to weaning from mechanical ventilation include mild hypervolemia, mental status changes, and periodic agitation. The plan is to improve hypervolemia with CVVH, bring PEEP down from 10 to 8, and attempt to switch to PSV if tolerating fluid coming off. Metoprolol will be given IV if the patient becomes tachycardic during PSV.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of renal failure, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, and type 1 diabetes mellitus. He was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient also has a retroperitoneal bleed (RP bleed), which has been complicated by hypoxemic respiratory failure and persistent renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure and is on mechanical ventilation. There may be a need to adjust ventilator settings or consider tracheostomy if extubation is not possible due to mental status.
2. Fevers: The patient had fevers, which were initially attributed to an infection. Further investigation and management are required.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has chronic renal failure, and his renal function needs to be closely monitored. CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) has been restarted.
4. Hypotension: The patient required pressor support but is now off neosynephrine. Close monitoring of blood pressure is necessary.
5. RP Bleed: The patient has a retroperitoneal bleed, which needs ongoing assessment and management.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and amiodarone has been continued with occasional Lopressor administration.

Other Issues:
The patient's nutrition, glycemic control,

   This is a 69yo man with history of CABG, atrial fibrillation with
   pacer/defibrillator on coumadin, systolic CHF (most recent echo in [**2188**]
   improved), and DMII who p/w acute onset of R-sided flank pain on
   [**2190-10-30**].   Abdominal CT showed evidence of right perirenal bleed
   possibly from a renal cyst.  Patient transferred to ICU for multiple
   reasons including possible UGIB, hypoxia and possible AMI.
   ## Hypoxia: Multifactorial: Klebsiella pneumonia; fluid overload from
   receiving multiple BP (has CHF); abdominal distension.
   - treatment for klebsiella PNA and enterococcus UTI complete
   - start Vancomycin empirically for GPCs on sputum GS , should cover for
   enterococcus also (day 4)
   - Continues to be mildly hypervolemic on exam.  On CVVH, net negative
   yesterday, goal today....
   - Barriers to weaning to PSV:  became tachycardic upon switch and
   mildly hypervolemic and mental-status wise awake but periodically
   agitated; otherwise, pneumonia seems to have improved per CXR,
   abdominal distension improved.  To address these barriers and wean,
   will need to improve hypervolemia with CVVH as discussed.  Did not
   tolerate decrease in PEEP to 8.  yesterday, continue to try to wean and
   attempt switch to PSV
   If becomes tachycardic, give IV metoprolol and try to maintain PSV.
   For agitation, can try giving one-time doses of benzos to try to come
   down on sedation.
   ## Atrial Fibrillation with RVR:  patient with irregular wide complex
   tachycardia up to 140
s becoming symptomatic with chest discomfort and
   dyspnea.  Will continue to rate control as needed.  Couple days ago had
   episode in setting of hypertension to 200s during period of
   extubation.  Continues to flip in an out of this morphology on tele.
   12.5 mg metoprolol added TID with improved pressures (130-140/60 and HR
   in low 90s).  Also require some IV metoprolol when HR elevated.
   - Cardiac enzymes stable
   - EP saw patient and felt pacer was functioning appropriately
   - control HR with  metoprolol 5 mg IV prn
   ## Abdominal distension
 likely secondary to ileus: KUB shows lots of
   air + stool in bowel:
   -Continuing aggressive PO bowel regimen
 po narcan
   - reduced NG output
   - nutrition rec low volume elemental diet started yesterday
   ## Acute / Chronic Renal Failure:  [**3-1**] to ATN from sustained
   hypotension and intraparenchymal bleed on chornic kidney disease.
   Secondly, the rupture of the renal cyst may have further compromised
   renal function; may have reached new baseline.  Creatinine stable, now
   2.7.   Again made 335cc over 24 hrs (20 ccs/hr)
   - Continue CVVH as above
   - Renally dosing meds, avoiding nephrotoxic agents.
   -Touch base w/ renal re: HD vs CVVH
   ## Retroperitoneal Bleed: patient with intraparrenchymal / subcapsular
   bleed of right kidney possibly secondary to cyst rupture in setting of
   high INR from coumadin.  HCTs are currently stable. Patient is now s/p
   4 units PRBC
s and 7 units FFP to help support hemodynamics and reverse
   INR.   Hct tredning down slowly likely a combination of slow blood loss
   and reduced reticulyte count given renal disease.  Rets appropriately.
   No evidence of hemolysis.
   -HCTs continue to be stable
   -daily HCTs.  PRBC transfusion for goal > 25 and FFP transfusion for
   INR goal < 1.9
   -holding ASA and coumadin
   ## Fevers/leukocytosis -  Febrilex1 overnight and WBC has trended down.
   -  F/u catheter tip cxs, sputum cxs, bcxs, repeated.
   ## Concern for UGIB:  Multiple times coffee-ground material suctioned
   from OG tube.  Hematocrit stable.  Likely secondary to old prior bleed;
   source unclear.   [**Name2 (NI) 133**] continue to follow HCT.
   -Will continue IV PPI
   -maintain active type and screen
   # DMII: Diagnosed seven years ago, most recent HgA1C: 8.5% as of [**Month (only) 435**]
   [**2190**].  Enteral nutrition re-initiated; can stop insulin drip and
   re-start on home lantus today of 44 and cover with HISS; adjust doses
   as necessary.
   - on Lantus and SSI
   #Hypothyroidism:  continue levothyroxine sodium 125 mcg
   #Gout: allopurinol 100 mg every other day given poor GFR (renally
   dosed)
   # FEN: Start TF per nutrition, Avoiding IVF, replete electrolytes as
   necessary.

   # Access: d/c L IJ, peripherals,  HD line replaced on right.

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of renal failure, type I diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, and chronic kidney disease. He is currently admitted to the ICU due to acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and a retroperitoneal bleed.

The patient has been febrile overnight and is agitated, with increased sedation required. He has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs show tachycardia, hypertension, and hypoxemia.

Laboratory results indicate anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and abnormal liver function tests. Electrolyte levels are within normal range. Imaging studies reveal a retroperitoneal bleed in the area of a previous cyst.

The patient's medical complications include delirium, alteration in nutrition, respiratory failure, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, acute heart failure, diabetes mellitus, chronic renal failure, and obstructive sleep apnea.

The assessment and plan include the following:

1) Respiratory failure: Continue current vent management, ongoing fluid removal, and hemodialysis today.
2) Fevers: Ongoing fevers, reculture overnight. Will continue vancomycin and reinstitute gram-negative coverage.
3) Renal failure: Hemodialysis today.
4) Hypotension: Pressors off currently.
5) RP bleed: Hct stable.
6) Atrial fibrillation: Amiodarone,
